part of the People's Republic of China
but it has its own legal system and
police force Hong Kong is distinct
enough that the youth identifies itself
as a separate group from their mainland
kin to get the full picture we need a
course in history in 1842 the Chinese
emperor ceded Hong Kong Island to the
British in perpetuity bringing an end to
the First Opium War China later ceded
Kowloon Peninsula in 1860 ending the
Second Opium War shortly after the first
sino-japanese war in 1898 Britain
pressured China to leave the New
Territories for a duration of 99 years
collectively the concessions make up
what is modern Hong Kong and if it were
up to the British they would never have
returned it to China for a while the
communist leadership in Beijing approved
of the British rule they came to rely on
Hong Kong as a gateway for Western
technology trade and finances since the
city-state was better integrated in
to the global economy than the mainland
Hong Kong could do business under more
flexible rules the city's legal
regulations allowed it to raise capital
in different ways and permitted the
movement of goods and people with
greater tolerance than China soon enough
Hong Kong became an indispensable medium
for interacting with the global economy
for espionage for backdoor diplomacy etc
in Hong Kong the Beijing government
could get things done that it otherwise
could not in the mainland itself this
bargaining chip gave Hong Kong leverage
and it's a relationship with Beijing in
the 1980s Margaret Thatcher attempted to
renew the lease on the new territories
not only did Angela pin reject the
request but he went as far as to claim
sovereignty over all of Hong Kong
including Hong Kong Island which had
been ceded to the British in perpetuity
Britain was not the empire it used to be
and Thatcher had no choice but to
capitulate to tangs demands under the
handover agreement British Hong Kong
would returned to China in 1997 part of
the arrangement was that Hong Kong would
retain its legal system borders and
government for the next 50 years and
just like that the one country two
systems' principle was invented however
Britain had failed to introduce a
working democratic system in Hong Kong
before the handover leaving the city
with a political organisation that
combined limited democratic elections
with a powerful chief executive that was
appointed by a Council of political and
business elites Hong Kong was an
oligarchy at the time however the local
government looked to its economic weight
as an assurance that its autonomy would
be respected in 1993 for example Hong
Kong's economy equal to 27 percent of
China's GDP but any egalitarian
agreement where one side of numbers the
others population by nearly 200 fold is
doomed to fail Hong Kong's supposed
autonomy was always going to pay
on Beijing swill to uphold it at around
the time that China assumed sovereignty
over Hong Kong many state enterprises
were liquidated and their assets sold to
private investors as China accelerated
its privatization program cities like
Shanghai Guangzhou Shenzhen Tianjin and
others developed rapidly meanwhile Hong
Kong's share of China's GDP took a
nosedive
to the current 2.9 percent as soon as
Hong Kong's economic weight diminished
Beijing started chipping at the city's
autonomy by exploiting the faulty
government structure the electoral
process increasingly excluded anti
Beijing parties and candidates until
eventually the city's political and
business elite switched allegiances to
Beijing the Hong Kong oligarchy
including the chief executive came to be
dominated by the Communist Party
subsequently the mainland government
used its influence to appoint and
promote loyalists within the Hong Kong
government thereby curbing the power of
the city's elected Legislative Council
the process thus far had been the easy
part assimilating Hong Kong's population
was going to be a whole lot more
complicated Britain had ruled Hong Kong
for 156 years the local culture revolved
around a different set of values from
those under the Communist mainland
residents of Hong Kong expected the
right to criticise and innovate while
embracing their Chinese and Western
customs a study by Hong Kong
University's public opinion programme
found that the youth of the city doesn't
even identify as Chinese just 3 point 1
percent of those under 30 years felt
Chinese with the vast majority seeing
themselves as a distinct group in
addition the study immigration of
mainland Chinese to Hong Kong sent
real-estate prices soaring driven by
demand from mainland buyers Hong Kong's
property barons nearly doubled home
prices between 2009 and 2013 as tensions
developed between local residents and
their
and kin public discontent grew
anti-government protests were inevitable
and Beijing assumed as much in the last
few years numerous Hong Kong activists
have been abducted lawmakers have been
removed foreign journalists have lost
their visas and anti-communist lectures
have been shut down several of these
events triggered mass protests in Hong
Kong but only once in 2013 did Beijing
back down every other time Beijing
shrugged and waited for the momentum to
wane including in the 2014 protests when
about half a million people occupied
Central Hong Kong the result for the
current movement is likely to be the
same on the other hand if this level of
unrest had taken place in any other
Chinese city the state would have
repressed it without reservations
Beijing's restraint shows that the
principle of one country two systems'
remains very much alive however the very
thing that makes Hong Kong a valuable
asset also makes it an extraordinary
danger the made in China 2025 which we
covered in a previous report seeks to
transform the mainland economy from the
top-down such drastic reforms are bound
to trigger social upheavals across the
country as a precautionary measure the
Communist Party seated political power
to President Xi Jinping with the hope
that he will steady the ship in doing so
she has systematically purged political
opponents and made it legally possible
for him to govern indefinitely no leader
since Deng Xiaoping has held this much
political power and the country has
become more repressive as a result Hong
Kong however is not fully under Beijing
s control and the cabinet of she fears
that the city could act as a Trojan
horse while the made in China reforms
shake up the socio-economic status quo
in the mainland as such she needs
complete control as his government
enacts the calming nationwide reforms
otherwise he risks another perestroika
and glasnost which caused the Soviet
leadership dearly
thus China's objective is to retain Hong
Kong's commercial value while limiting
its political influence Beijing cannot
allow Hong Kong to become a platform for
political dissidents uncooperative
conglomerates media tycoons and so on
hence the recently proposed extradition
bill eventually Beijing will win the

nearly every other time when it decided
to flex its authority that said
President Xi has a strong incentive to
preserve the facade of self-rule in Hong
Kong for most the city is the financial

plus at the backdrop of the
chinese-american trade war Hong Kong's
regulations are useful for those seeking

apply its experience in integrating Hong

managed to do this without having to

forces this gradual erosion of Hong
